Malachite is a green mineral. It gets its colour from copper (it is a carbonate of copper), and fizzes when tested with a drop of dilute hydrochloric acid. Malachite is an opaque (the opposite of transparent) mineral, and often has a distinctive pattern of concentric banding. Malachite is relatively soft, and is often carved into ornaments. It is also a popular semi precious gemstone. Malachite is found in many localities, including Zaire, Australia, Russia and the USA.

Tourmaline is a semi precious gemstone that occurs in a wide range of colours. This particular type, with a red core and a green outer layer is commonly described as watermelon tourmaline, for obvious reasons. Tourmaline is widely used in jewellery. This mineral is strongly pleochroic, which means that it appears to be differently coloured when viewed along different crystal axes (different directions), a property which helps to distinguish it from the many other gemstones with which it may be confused.

The difference between green aquamarines and emerald (also a variety of beryl) is that emeralds are classified (in the UK), as stones deriving their colour from the element chromium. Aquamarines are popular gemstones, but are often treated to improve their colour. Aquamarine crystals are six sided (hexagonal) and can grow to very large sizes.

Rhodonite is a popular decorative stone, and is often carved to make ornaments.

The only known source of this material in the ancient world was in Afghanistan, so the Egyptians used artifical materials like blue glass (in the funeral mask of Tutankhamun), and 'Egyptian blue' for their wall paintings and coffins, as substitutes for this rare commodity.
